segments.text: On the second side, we're now departing Caldwell.
A three or four page syllabus which tried to explain as clearly, simply, plainly as possible what the course covered.
and how grades would be calculated.
Never, never, never did I grade on a curve and always tried to persuade
the group, but I hoped every one of them would make an A, but that my experience had led me to believe that the odds were comparatively small or comparatively high that such
a circumstance would probably not occur.
That explanation of grades included how the papers were graded, what each of the tests counted in terms of the semester grade, so that they would always be able to calculate how they were
progressing during the semester.
At first, I gave all essay tests, but as the sections got larger, we mixed essays and multiple choice questions.
In those multiple choice questions, I always tried to select at least a few questions from every lecture.
But an equal number from the text alone and about another third
from text that were included in both text and lectures.
Thus, in the opening lecture, I tried to emphasize to the students that if they hoped to make a high grade, they would need to be present each day
take notes which they studied regularly, and also read their text regularly.
I urged them to read the text before they came to class, following the listing in the syllabus of each lecture, each day's lecture topic, and the readings
which related to that material.

Thus, if they read the material in advance and either underline or highlighted what seemed to be the most important points, they would have a, quote, distilled version, quote, of the textual information before hearing the lecture.
Then, if they took adequate notes during the lecture, I begged them to review those notes before they went to sleep on the same day of that class meeting.
Finally, my counsel was that once a week, if they would review again their class notes and the text, the highlighted material in the text, they would begin to refine the material
and file it away in their cranial computer.
Then, when the test came, which were given about once a month, three tests plus the final, they would
be able then to review the material which they had been learning gradually through the semester.
In my opinion, the worst of all possible styles for handling the course for a student was to postpone everything and then try to bone up
in the wee hours one or two nights before the test.
That, to me, was particularly inadvisable for the final exam.
Paragraph.
For all of those years, I checked the roll every day in every section.

trying to explain in the syllabus that whether they attended or not was their business and that there was no punishment for their being absent, but that if they were present for every class meeting with a maximum of two absences, then they could drop the low grade prior to the final exam.
Thus, there was a reward for being present.
And because of the number of students and the fact that there was no deduction for absences, I would not entertain material, I would not review their materials relating to, quote, excused absences.
excuse absent, put that in quotation marks, dash, thus they were either present or absent.
And for being present regularly, there was a return, there was a distinctive return on their investment of time.
In delivering the lectures, while I had my lecture outlines up on the front of the lectern, I tended to move around a great deal in the front of the room, believing that that process would help to
discourage sleepers, non-note takers, and other youngsters who were daydreaming.
Sometimes there were attempts, sometimes I made attempts to tease a youngster who was obviously not listening to the lecture.
or to feign deep discouragement over such a practice.
On those occasions when I found a youngster asleep, back up, in that paragraph, in that first
class meeting.

I always told the students that if we found someone asleep, we would try to wake them up and then ask them to stand and give their name, hometown, high school name, and sing the high school fight song.
On the comparatively few times in all of those years of teaching that someone did go to sleep.
And I followed that routine.
I always tried to be very sure to speak
personally with that student immediately after class to assure them that there was no continuing anger on my part.
In addition, I wanted to ensure that there was not some personal problem which was handicapping that student
and which I should help to solve.
At A&M, the students, particularly in the early years when the Corps members filled all the freshman classes, the students were accustomed
the following directions.
And they quickly followed the directions which I placed on them.
Because of my own small town and working class experience,
I was able to identify with these young men sooner than I realized at the time.
Some of them were short of cash, but almost all of them
were well supplied with dreams, ambition, and determination.
Occasionally, there were a few pranks in class, like some fish trying to give a core sophomore a hot foot.
are putting some well chewed gum in a late arrivers seat.
Possibly someone tried to come to class on behalf of a friend, but I never was aware
of any attempt at such a practice.
I do remember one year when the students learned that I collected bricks from historic buildings
Someone from the back of the room asked if I had anything from the Alamo and of course I responded by saying no and that surely no one would dare touch such a sacred spot.
A few weeks later the first class session after the
returned from spring break, a trio of smiling fish came up to the lectern after the others departed.
They mentioned the question about the Alamo and smiled as one of their group placed a hunk
of gray limestone placed a small bundle of, a small item wrapped in newspapers on the lector.
As I opened it,
It was obviously a piece of gray limestone.
And I simply said you did.
And they smiled and said, why not?
We thought you'd enjoy it.
When I asked them.
What part of the building did they attack?
They said the Southwest.
Corner of the exterior.
And a few months later.
When I had.
When I passed through.
The Alamo City.
I walked to that part of the.

I noticed that the.

A dent.
In the corner.
of the building where apparently a piece of rock had been knocked loose recently.

in a 105 class.
But I think I've already talked about that one.
So I should not continue that.
Now let's jump to
Beginning the task with Dr. Calhoun, my next door office mate, who welcomed me with a broad smile, was Richard E. Winerdi, W-A-I-N-E-R-D-I.
a marvelously talented petroleum engineer who had studied with Dr. Calhoun in New York and at Oklahoma and at Pennsylvania State University.
I don't believe I have ever served with a more talented
and broad and broadly, brightly inquisitive individual than Dick Quinerty.
Some of my associates quickly told me that of their
frustration with him at his sharp temperament and quick decision making.
I never saw that side of his personality because with me, he was always tirelessly thoughtful, helpful, and considerate.
Although engineering was his official field of study, he was well-read and curiously inquisitive in an almost limitless horizon of subjects.
Paragraph, as we began our task, he was the associate vice president for academic affairs.
I, the assistant, and Dr. Calhoun, the vice president.
Winerdi and I attacked the total spectrum
of work on the campus.
And there was no clearly defined separation of responsibilities.
Yet he primarily looked at science, engineering, and technology
and I, social sciences, humanities, education, business, et cetera.
Also, teaching anything related to instruction came to my desk first while research and service went to his.
Paragraph, Dr. Calhoun always wanted to be well-informed about every topic of general interest, and so there were many, many conversations with him, both brief and extended.
throughout the months, throughout the years.
In some instances, that meant simply to pop into his office and mention a topic quickly or to engage in an extended discussion
At the end of the day, following the departure of all of the other staff members.
Before very before.
Very long in the Calhoun.
Years.
There was a.
separate research office that adjoined ours.
And when my title changed to dean of faculties, all faculty matters of appointments, promotion, tenure
and any problems relating to those matters became my responsibility.
Paragraph.
On the many occasions when Dr. Calhoun was on the road, be it Austin, Washington, or anywhere else, when Erdie and I would try to have all of his correspondence
surveyed with the draft responses to every communication, typed and ready for his signature, waiting for him to return and review them,
On the conference table on the long table in the conference room adjoining his office in the Teague building.
Quite often.
When dark Calhoun came back on the last flight.
To Easterwood Airport in that.
In the late evening.
He would stop on the campus to review that material.
And thankfully seldom.
Found.
Problem with our drafts.
Thus.
He could spend the next day looking forward.
Instead of having to.
spend time with his responses.
One of the key introductions for me to the relationship of a nerdy and Calhoun came at the end of my first official day
as a member of their squad.
I walked with Dr. Winerdi into Dr. Calhoun's office, perhaps at 5.30 or so, and they began to discuss some key issue.
Vice President Calhoun
throughout his opinion, and as well as the manner in which he had reached a conclusion.
My startled ear then heard Dick Winerdi say something like, quote,
You don't know what you're talking about.
That's a dumb idea.
Why would you want to do something like that?
Period quote.
As a naive member of an administrative team, I was stunned that a subordinate would dare speak to his chief officer in that fashion.
Quickly I learned, however, that John Calhoun proudly listened to an explanation from an individual that he knew was speaking to him honestly and sincerely.
That same circumstance occurred to me.
A similar circumstance occurred to me in about a month.
When I went with Dr. Calhoun to a meeting of the library committee and typist, I think I've already shared that one.
If not, leave a blank space and I will.

Another place and time of Calhoun leadership, for examples of Calhoun leadership, was the gathering of the APC- the Academic Programs Committee, Academic Programs Council, which was in fact a gathering of the deans.
Yours truly was added to that group.
My first week.
In the Teague building.
It would include the Deans.
Plus.
Ed Cooper, who was the director of admissions and records.
And would in later years.
be titled also as a dean.
That session, normally held at 1 30 on Monday afternoons, was the true academic staff session.
Paragraph.
Gathered around the table was a group which in hindsight, Dash, obviously it was outstanding.
It included Fred Benson, the Dean of Engineering, a comparatively quiet, reserved man.
